details.title: An Exponential Damage Model for Strength of Fibrous Composite Materials
details.standardTitle: An Exponential Damage Model for Strength of Fibrous Composite Materials

p: William J. Owen received his Ph.D. (1997) in Statistics from the University of South Carolina. From 1997 to 2002, he was an Assistant Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of New Hampshire. Currently, he is an Associate Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science at the University of Richmond. He has published papers on reliability, life testing, parametric inference, and the security of volunteer distributed computations. He is an Associate Editor for the J. Statistical Computation and Simulation, and he is a member of the American Statistical Association.

details.abstract: When modeling experimental data observed from carefully performed tensile strength tests, statistical distributions are typically used to describe the strength of composite specimens. Recently, cumulative damage models derived for predicting tensile strength have been shown to be superior to other models when used to fit composite strength data. Here, an alternative model is developed which is based on an exponential cumulative damage approach. The model is shown to exhibit a similar structural form to the other models in the literature so that previous theory for cumulative damage models can be utilized to find parameter estimates.

links.abstract: The assumption of a common underlying failure process leads to both the inverse Gaussian distribution and the fatigue life distribution of Birnbaum & Saunders. The first is obtained by an exact derivation while the second involves certain approximations. Although both of these distributions fit many failure data well, the inverse Gaussian distribution enjoys a distinct advantage in regard to the availability of procedures for a sound statistical analysis and tractability of the sampling distribu...

links.abstract: The relationship between two fatigue life distributions, namely the Birnbaum-Saunders and the Inverse Gaussian, is further investigated. An intimate connection exists between the two models, viz, the Birnbaum-Saunders is a mixture of two probability distributions: 1) an Inverse Gaussian random variable, and 2) the reciprocal of an Inverse Gaussian random variable. Advantages and disadvantages of the two distributions are discussed. The arguments favour the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution from a s...

models

context.text: A summary of the recent research can be found in [11], [12], but of importance here are the models based on a “cumulative damage” approach first described in [4], and later revisited in [6].

As assumed in [6], [12], the “initial strength” of a composite specimen is taken to be a reduction of the theoretical strength of the specimen, denoted by \$\psi\$, by some random amount, denoted by \${\rm X}_{0}\$.
Herein, we use the I-G approximation to the ECD model, similar to the procedures used in [6], [9], [12].

Durham & Padgett [6] describe, in general, the amount of cumulative damage accrued after \$n+1\$ increments of stress as \${\rm X}_{n+1}={\rm X}_{n}+{\rm D}_{n} h({\rm X}_{n})\$, where \${\rm D}_{n}\$ is the damage incurred at load increment \$n+1\$, and \$h(u)\$ is an assumed damage model function.
In [6], an additive model is assumed with \$h(u)=1\$ for all \$u\$.
We will consider the “Gaussian-tails” Cdf from [6] (also used in [12]) which has a pdf defined by .
Other models for initial strength have been considered; a Weibull model was used in [6], and a stochastic processes approach was considered in [14].
Here, we use (3) because it was shown to be superior in [6], [11]; and so a direct comparison to the other C-D models using this initial strength model can be made.

Using arguments similar to those in [6], [12], the portion of the integral outside of the \$s\$-normal Cdf in (4) is a gamma density (for the random variable V) with shape parameter 1/2 & scale parameter \$2{\rm L}/(n\sigma^{2})\$.
Also, it can be seen that (7) is a B-S type distribution that is similar to the results found in [6], [12], and later integrated in [11].
Both [6] & [12] use an I-G approximation for the additive & multiplicative cumulative damage models derived; here, we can do the same as follows (a B-S approach for C-D models is described in [11]).
The I-G theory for the cumulative damage models derived in [6], [12] was unified in [9], and from their article it can easily be seen that the ECD model (7) also complies with their framework.
Durham & Padget [6] fit their “additive Gauss-Gauss” C-D model, and later the “multiplicative Gauss-Gauss” C-D model was used in [6].
In this article a strength model based on the C-D methodology from [6] has been described.

As mentioned previously, the three C-D models discussed herein follow the structure (3), with the “additive Gauss-Gauss” model [6] having acceleration functions \$\Lambda_{\rm A}(\psi;{\rm L})=\psi-\sqrt{2{\rm L}/\pi}\$ & \$\Lambda_{\rm M}(\psi;{\rm L})=\ln(\psi)-(\sqrt{2\pi/{\rm L}}/\psi)-({\rm L}/2\psi^{2})\$ for the “multiplicative Gauss-Gauss” model [12].

context.text: Section IV demonstrates fitting the ECD model to both carbon micro-composite tensile strength data observed by [1], and carbon fiber tensile strength data from [8].
The second dataset is from [8] where individual PAN carbon fibers are considered to evaluate their tensile strength properties.
The “additive Gauss-Gauss,” and the “multiplicative Gauss-Gauss” were used to fit the data from [8].

context.text: Herein, we use the I-G approximation to the ECD model, similar to the procedures used in [6], [9], [12].
The I-G theory for the cumulative damage models derived in [6], [12] was unified in [9], and from their article it can easily be seen that the ECD model (7) also complies with their framework.

Both [9] & [11] depict the function \$\Lambda_{\rm E}(\psi;{\rm L})\$ as an “acceleration function” because it is a decreasing function of L, and the incorporation of the length variable L is similar to the theory of accelerated life tests [7].
Using the result from [9], the MLE for \$\mu\$, and \$\sigma\$ in (8) are given respectively by .

Onar & Padgett [9] also give details for acquiring starting values for estimation procedures via a simple “least squares” approach, as well as methods for the calculation of asymptotic confidence intervals for MLE based on the Fisher information matrix.
An overall summary is given in [9].
A formula for this quantity can be found, e.g. in [9].
The MSE is given in Table II, along with the other models reported in [9].
In addition, for evaluation purposes, we include the results from the “inverse linear model” for the I-G distribution as reported in [9].
The MSE is given in Table III, along with the other models reported in [9].
That being said, [9] argue that the C-D approach is perhaps not appropriate for single fiber strength data.
The ECD, based on a specific damage model function, achieves a unique model, but still adheres to the C-D theory presented in [9].

context.text: A summary of the recent research can be found in [11], [12], but of importance here are the models based on a “cumulative damage” approach first described in [4], and later revisited in [6].
Here, we use (3) because it was shown to be superior in [6], [11]; and so a direct comparison to the other C-D models using this initial strength model can be made.
Also, it can be seen that (7) is a B-S type distribution that is similar to the results found in [6], [12], and later integrated in [11].
Both [6] & [12] use an I-G approximation for the additive & multiplicative cumulative damage models derived; here, we can do the same as follows (a B-S approach for C-D models is described in [11]).

Both [9] & [11] depict the function \$\Lambda_{\rm E}(\psi;{\rm L})\$ as an “acceleration function” because it is a decreasing function of L, and the incorporation of the length variable L is similar to the theory of accelerated life tests [7].
We have computed the MSE for the “Multiplicative Gauss-Gauss” model from [11] using the Bader Priest data to be 0.00445, and this gives a slight edge to the ECD presented here.

links.abstract: Knowledge of the tensile strength properties of a fibrous composite material is essential in the design of reliable structures from that material. Determination of statistical models for the tensile strength of a composite material which provide good fits to experimental data from tensile tests on material specimens is therefore important for engineering design. Perhaps the most commonly used statistical model is the Weibull distribution, based on 'weakest link of a chain' arguments. However, in...

context.text: For these types of measurements, the typical candidates include the Weibull & lognormal distributions, but these distributions do not adequately fit experimental strength data from fibrous composites [12].
A summary of the recent research can be found in [11], [12], but of importance here are the models based on a “cumulative damage” approach first described in [4], and later revisited in [6].

As assumed in [6], [12], the “initial strength” of a composite specimen is taken to be a reduction of the theoretical strength of the specimen, denoted by \$\psi\$, by some random amount, denoted by \${\rm X}_{0}\$.
Herein, we use the I-G approximation to the ECD model, similar to the procedures used in [6], [9], [12].
Later, a multiplicative model is derived in [12], where \$h(u)=u\$ for all \$u\$.
We will consider the “Gaussian-tails” Cdf from [6] (also used in [12]) which has a pdf defined by .
Similar to the development in [12], applying the transformation \$v=(\psi-w)^{2}/(n\sigma^{2})\$ in the above yields .

Using arguments similar to those in [6], [12], the portion of the integral outside of the \$s\$-normal Cdf in (4) is a gamma density (for the random variable V) with shape parameter 1/2 & scale parameter \$2{\rm L}/(n\sigma^{2})\$.

To evaluate (6), we will use a three-term Taylor series approximation about \$\psi\$ (in [12], a Taylor series approximation was also used to approximate an expectation) for the function \$\ln[\ln(\psi-\sqrt{\rm L}x)]\$.
Also, it can be seen that (7) is a B-S type distribution that is similar to the results found in [6], [12], and later integrated in [11].
Both [6] & [12] use an I-G approximation for the additive & multiplicative cumulative damage models derived; here, we can do the same as follows (a B-S approach for C-D models is described in [11]).
The I-G theory for the cumulative damage models derived in [6], [12] was unified in [9], and from their article it can easily be seen that the ECD model (7) also complies with their framework.

As mentioned previously, the three C-D models discussed herein follow the structure (3), with the “additive Gauss-Gauss” model [6] having acceleration functions \$\Lambda_{\rm A}(\psi;{\rm L})=\psi-\sqrt{2{\rm L}/\pi}\$ & \$\Lambda_{\rm M}(\psi;{\rm L})=\ln(\psi)-(\sqrt{2\pi/{\rm L}}/\psi)-({\rm L}/2\psi^{2})\$ for the “multiplicative Gauss-Gauss” model [12].

links.abstract: Based on a generalized cumulative damage approach with a stochastic process describing initial damage for a material specimen, a broad class of statistical models for material strength is developed. Plausible choices of stochastic processes for the initial damage include Brownian motion, geometric Brownian motion, and the gamma process; and additive & multiplicative cumulative damage functions are considered. The resulting general statistical model gives an accelerated test form of the inverse G...
